qas.question: From what Old English dialect is the standard for of Modern English descended?
From what Old English dialect did Scots derive?
What modern dialect is sometimes regarded as being similar to that of the historical Kingdom of Wessex?
Along with centralization, what reason is given for the lack of records in non-Wessex dialects after the unification of Alfred?
What dialects disappeared after Alfred's unification?
What scholars lead the movement to translate texts into English?
What languages are descended from Mercian and West Saxon?
What was the capital of the Anglo-Saxon kingdom?

context: Due to the centralisation of power and <a3_0>the Viking invasions<a3_0/>, there is relatively little written record of the <b4_0>non-Wessex dialects<b4_0/> after Alfred's unification. Some Mercian texts continued to be written, however, and the influence of <b5_0>Mercian<b5_0/> is apparent in some of the translations produced under Alfred's programme, many of which were produced by Mercian scholars. Other dialects certainly continued to be spoken, as is evidenced by the continued variation between their successors in <b6_0>Middle and Modern English<b6_0/>. In fact, what would become the standard forms of Middle English and of Modern English are descended from <a0_0>Mercian<a0_0/> rather than West Saxon, while Scots developed from the <a1_0>Northumbrian<a1_0/> dialect. It was once claimed that, owing to its position at the heart of the Kingdom of Wessex, the relics of Anglo-Saxon accent, idiom and vocabulary were best preserved in the dialect of <a2_0><b7_0>Somerset<b7_0/><a2_0/>.
